question.name: OrfsByLocation
question.summary: Find Orfs that are located in a specified genomic region.
question.description: If your organism does not appear in the drop down menu, indicates your genome of interest exists in scaffold/supercontig format. Try searching by filling in the Genomic Sequence ID e.g; HyaarEmoy2_SC0001

Find ORFs within a given genomic region.
Select a B. bovis, T. annulata, or T. parva chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter a genomic sequence ID. (If you supply both, your result will include the union). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs within a given genomic region.
Enter a genomic sequence ID for any E. histolytica, E. dispar or E. invadens contig. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the sequence.

Find ORFs that are located in a specified genomic region.

Either select a E. intestinalis or E. cuniculi chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter a sequence ID of a chromosome (e.g. "TGME49_chrIa") or a scaffold (e.g. "DS984781").
If you enter both, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs within a given genomic region.
Select a C. parvum chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter the name of a contig for either C. parvum or C. hominis(e.g."AAEL01000057"). If you enter both, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs that are located in a specified genomic region.

Either select an organism and chromosome from the pull-down menus or enter a genomic sequence ID from any Plasmodium species (if you supply both, your result will include the union). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs within a given genomic region.
Either select an organism and a genomic sequence from the pull-down menu or enter a genomic sequence ID from any EuPathDB species (e.g. "AAEL01000057", "Pf3D7_04_v3", "TGME49_chrIa", "ctg02_305", "DS170425"). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs within a given genomic region.
Enter a genomic sequence ID for any T. vaginalis contig. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs within a given genomic region.
Enter a genomic sequence ID for any G. lamblia contig. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the sequence.

Find ORFs that are located in a specified genomic region.

Either select a T. gondii chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter a sequence ID of a chromosome (e.g. "TGME49_chrIa") or a scaffold (e.g. "DS984781").
If you enter both, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

Find ORFs that are located in a specified genomic region.

Either select an organism and chromosome from the pull-down menus or enter a genomic sequence ID from any species (if you supply both, your result will include the union).
The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the ORF(s) on the chromosome.

question.name: OrfByOrfId
question.description: If your organism does not appear in the drop down menu, indicates your genome of interest exists in scaffold/supercontig format. Try searching by filling in the Genomic Sequence ID e.g; HyaarEmoy2_SC0001

Find open reading frames (ORFs) by a list of IDs. The ORF ID and sequences may change from release to release if the genomic sequence changes.
The ORF naming system is designed to:
  • Specify the name of the DNA sequence producing the ORF, e.g. %%defaultGenome%%
  • The Frame (1-6) the ORF was found in, e.g. 1
  • The span, in nucleotides, encoding the ORF, e.g. 24160-24672
  • Putting it all together: %%defaultGenome%%-1-24160-24672
Note: This is an example, which may or may not be a valid ORF ID.

Either enter the ID list manually, or upload a file that contains the list. IDs can be delimited by a comma, a semi colon, or any white spaces.

question.name: OrfsByMotifSearch
question.summary: Find orfs with a motif pattern that you specify, e.g.: two cysteines followed by one or more hydrophobic amino acids, followed by arginine, then lysine.
question.description:
Find genes whose protein product contains a motif pattern that you specify.

Specify the pattern with a (Perl style) "regular expression". (Regular expressions are more powerful than PROSITE patterns.) For a description of how to create regular expressions, please see the Regular Expression Tutorial.
